Welcome to "English in a Minute," where we teach you about idioms in American English.
If you have heard American English, you have probably heard this:...
There's no need for you to pay 20 dollars for that hairbrush, it's too expensive.
The store down the street has them at a dime a dozen.
When you say something is "a dime a dozen,"...
...it means that there's a lot of it, it doesn't cost much or that it isn't special.
This is a common way of saying that something is so easy to get that it doesn't have much value.
